user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_close:
```c
int32 OS_close(osal_id_t filedes)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Make sure the file descriptor is legit before using it */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, filedes, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_GenericClose_Impl(&token);

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_close:
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_GenericClose_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                             result;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    result = close(impl->fd);
    if (result < 0)
    {
        /*
         * close() can technically fail for various reasons, but
         * there isn't much recourse if this call fails.  Just log
         * the failure for debugging.
         *
         * POSIX also does not specify the state of the filehandle
         * after a close() with an error.
         *
         * At least in  Linux/glibc the filehandle is always closed
         * in the kernel and should not be used again or re-closed.
         */
        OS_DEBUG("close: %s\n", strerror(errno));
    }
    impl->fd = -1;
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(int32 operation_status, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    osal_id_t final_id;

    /* Clear the OSAL ID if successful - this returns the record to the pool */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        final_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;
    }
    else
    {
        /* this restores the original ID */
        final_id = token->obj_id;
    }

    /* Either way we must unlock the object type */
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, &final_id);

    /* Give event callback to the application */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_NotifyEvent(OS_EVENT_RESOURCE_DELETED, token->obj_id, NULL);
    }

    return operation_status;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I scanned the provided code for compiler-specific language extensions (e.g. __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, statement-expressions ({...}), nested functions, GCC/clang builtins, or other nonstandard keywords). None of those appear explicitly in the visible code or declarations. The remaining constructs are ordinary C (typedefs, function calls, pointer/struct access, return statements, macros used in a standard way). The three reported fragments are macro or callback invocations that could potentially expand to or wrap compiler-specific extensions (macros often hide compiler-specific constructs such as attributes, builtin functions, statement-expressions, or other extensions). These macro usages should be investigated by inspecting their definitions to ensure they do not rely on compiler-specific language extensions. All other code lines in the snippets provided do not show signs of using compiler extensions and therefore do not need further investigation for Rule 1.2 based on the visible code.
